title: Understanding the Lewis Structure
text: To determine the bond angle, molecular shape, and polarity, start by drawing the Lewis structure of NH₃. Recall that nitrogen has five valence electrons, forms three single bonds to hydrogen atoms, and retains one lone pair.

title: Determining the Bond Angle
text: Consider the electron pair geometry around nitrogen. A tetrahedral arrangement has an ideal bond angle of 109.5°, but the lone pair slightly compresses the H–N–H bond angle. What approximate angle does this create?

title: Identifying the Molecular Shape
text: The molecular shape is based only on the positions of the atoms (not lone pairs). With three bonding pairs and one lone pair on nitrogen, what is the name of this shape?

title: Checking for Polar Bonds
text: A polar bond occurs when there is a difference in electronegativity between the bonded atoms. Consider the electronegativities of nitrogen and hydrogen. Is there enough difference for the N–H bonds to be polar?

title: Determining Overall Polarity
text: To decide whether the molecule is polar, consider both the shape and the polar bonds. In a trigonal pyramidal shape, do the bond dipoles cancel out or create a net dipole moment?
